For those who want to know how accurate this movie is read my comment: if you are asking my opinion I would say that the movie is all Fictional and only based on Frank Miller comic-book called 300 as well as having some propaganda ant-Iranian messages which basically mis-represent the Persians as some sort of terrorist, evil, brutal and blood-thirstily empire which is not based in reality even do the theme of the movie was good vs Evil. However you going to hear some people saying that the movie is trying to re-creating the battle of Thermopylae, but everything you saw was not Historically accurate. let me tell you why

First of all the Persians did not dressed like Taliban or ISIS back in days as how they were depicted in that first movie and the Xerxes wasn‚Äôt a bald gay devil who wore gold chains and were half naked, the real man probably had some bears like what you saw in the second movie or maybe the long one. I don‚Äôt understand why they say is re-telling a story from the past even do the 99% of the movie is fake and there are many reasons for that.


Xerxes probably did not owned any slaves as like his father Darius the great he paid all of the workers who were building Persepolis, and Persia generally banned owning other people as slavery was something against their law and is something that is kind of almost unheard in Ancient Persia if you believe their tablets.Beside he also probably practiced the religion of Zoroastrian (believed in divine Power or god) like many other Persians. He did not considered himself a god (I haven‚Äôt heard something like that)


Moreover, not only owning slaves by the Persians was a lie but also the way how they portrayed false and distorted image of Ancient Persia who wanted to make a slaves from the Greeks and rape their women and destroy their cities if after they invaded their country.There is one epic scene in this movie where you going to see a Persian women wearing burqa and throwing magical bombs which something that was made up by Hollywood, Zack Snyder and Frank Miller themselves which was something that never happened and this movie is also trying to tell story from pre-Islamic pried of Iran (before the Arab conquest of Persia) which they not only forced their religion but also wanted to change their language like what they did Egypt; However unlike Egyptians the Persians are still speaking their own language but its been influenced a lot by Arabic, meaning they are many Arabic words in Persian as well as using their Alphabet instead of their old one.

just to make it as short as possible here are just the list for everything that is wrong or did not happened at that actual Event.

1.Persia wasn‚Äôt a Muslim Empire ( mainly Zoroastrians, who believed in good stuff and allowed freedom of worship)
2.The numbers are biased only comes from the Greek sources (mainly from the book of Herodotus) coming from their enemies and they did not used elephants
3.Persia wasn‚Äôt an evil ‚Äúterrorist‚Äù empire especially if you compare it to other cultures (re-search this on internet to find out more information)
4.Persian costumes are not correct/ as I said before, their women wearing Hijab and their men or Army dress like modern day Taliban or ISIS, Persia was a civilized culture.


5. Although Greece was civilized culture too, however they weren‚Äôt as nice as they been portrayed in this movie especially compare to what they been shown about the Persians. for instance they did indeed owned bunch of slaves unlike the Persians and their women ‚Äúin the ancient Greek world had few rights in comparison to male citizens. Unable to vote, own land, or inherit‚Äù whereas in ancient Persia there was one female who became navy commander as you saw in the second movie.

6.Women in Ancient Greece https://www.ancient.eu source Ancient History Encyclopedia this is where I have find about this information (ancient Greece women)

so not only Zack and Frank Miller exaggerate history but they also get everything backwards too.

7. In this case as you can see Persia was also democratic but there was not such a thing as voting (as far as we know or at least there is no proof to back it up)

8. at least but not least the Persian messengers did not fretted the Greek people to slavery and death as well as wanting to rape their women, with all the respect to all of my Greek fellows that was them who actually in fact not only killed them but also thrown them to garbage bin or (water well not too sure about that) Even do the king Xerxes wanted to capture their country without the war but it was rejected by them.

Title: 300: Rise of an Empire - Official Trailer 1 [HD]
Comment:
I don't understand why everyone hates this movie for vilifying the Persian Empire. It's literally a movie based off a comic book that looks at alternative takes on history. It's full of more action and themes like "Good Versus Evil". I for one enjoyed this movie but of cause I knew the majority of this wasn't correct at all, but it was still really fun to watch. Even if you are Persian today, there's no need to get so upset when they're simply changing events that happened thousands of years ago, because honestly there are a crap tonne of good films that like to unrealistically vilify other countries still around today.
Obviously though I recognize the film has a couple other problems like Character Development (though personally that didn't really bother me). I just think people need to chill a bit and start enjoying movies that like to ask "What If?"

After seizing the city, they continued their drive eastwards, following Yazdgird and his remaining troops. Within a short span of time, the Arab armies defeated a major Sassanid counter-attack in the Battle of Jal≈´lƒÅ', as well as other engagements at Qasr-e Shirin, and Masabadhan. By the mid-7th Century, the Arabs controlled all of Mesopotamia, including the area that is now the Iranian province of Khuzestan. It is said that Caliph Umar did not wish to send his troops through the Zagros mountains and onto the Iranian plateau. One tradition has it that he wished for a "wall of fire" to keep the Arabs and Persians apart. Later commentators explain this as a common-sense precaution against over-extension of his forces. The Arabs had only recently conquered large territories that still had to be garrisoned and administered. The continued existence of the Persian government was however an incitement to revolt in the conquered territories and unlike the Byzantine army, the Sassanid army was continuously striving to regain their lost territories. Finally Umar decided to push his forces for further conquests, which eventually resulted in the whole scale conquest of the Sassanid Empire. Yazdegerd, the Sassanid king, made yet another effort to regroup and defeat the invaders. By 641 he had raised a new force, which took a stand at the Battle of NihawƒÅnd, some forty miles south of Hamadan in modern Iran. The Rashidun army under the command of Umar's appointed general Nu'man ibn Muqarrin al-Muzani, attacked and again defeated the Persian forces. Title: 300: Rise of an Empire - Official Trailer 1 [HD]
Comment:
The Greeks: Crucible of Civilization¬†¬†v=r0T78tNS9u8
It was perhaps the most spectacular flourishing of imagination and achievement in recorded history. In the Fourth and Fifth Centuries BC, the Greeks built an empire that stretched across the Mediterranean from Asia to Spain. They laid the foundations of modern science, politics, warfare and philosophy, and produced some of the most breathtaking art and architecture the world has ever seen. This series, narrated by Liam Neeson, recounts the rise, glory, demise and legacy of the empire that marked the dawn of Western civilization. The story of this astonishing civilization is told through the lives of heroes of ancient Greece. The latest advances in computer and television technology rebuild the Acropolis, recreate the Battle of Marathon and restore the grandeur of the Academy, where Socrates, Plato and Aristotle forged the foundation of Western though. The series combines dramatic storytelling, stunning imagery, new research and distinguished scholarship to render classical Greece gloriously alive.
Empire of Mind
The final segment describes how Athens, at the height of her glory, engaged in a suicidal conflict with her greatest rival, Sparta. Through the eyes of Socrates, Athens' first philosopher, viewers see the tragic descent of Athenian democracy into mob rule.The episode opens in 399 B.C., after the great philosopher Socrates has been sentenced to death and Athens lies in ruins after a war with Sparta. This episode goes back to 431 B.C., to an Athens at the height of its cultural, political, and economic power. Having taken great leaps forward in every field of learning, and with a strong economy that dominates Mediterranean trade, Athens and its 150,000 residents are the envy of their neighbors, in particular, bellicose Sparta. Jealous of Athenian success, the Spartans yearn to spill Athenian blood and dominate the region. Of course, Pericles knows what is coming, and he orders the citizens to abandon open areas and take refuge inside the walls of Athens. The mighty Athenian fleet will provide supplies for the citizens through the port of Piraeus and a walled corridor between that city and Athens. Over time, the navy will prevail, as it had against the Persians, and win yet another victory. Much is at stake -- democracy, freedom, the whole Athenian way of life. As expected, the Spartans invade and burn the open areas around the city. But it is the unexpected that deals the most devastating blow to Athens. Incoming ships with supplies for the walled-in Greeks carry plague-bearing rats feeding on grain. The disease ravages the Athenians, inflicting agony on them and killing one out of every three. The Spartans are of little concern; what matters is surviving until tomorrow. Pericles' esteem plummets even as he himself contracts the plague and eventually dies. Finally in 404 B.C., Athens surrenders. The Athenians, shattered and stripped of their empire, take revenge on their most vocal critic and condemn Socrates to death before a people's court.

Title: 300: Rise of an Empire - Official Trailer 1 [HD]
Comment:
Watched this film like 3 times in the cinema and I honestly don't get the hate that this film gets from fans of the first film. I mean in my opinion, this film is equal in quality to the first film, in which I find it to be¬†a pretty solid in the story it wants to tell.

Like the first 300 film, this film does have a simple premise (and I do NOT care for historical accuracy). The first 300 film has the simple idea of freedom being worth fighting for and worth dying for. While this film does expand on that idea, it also has the premise of hell has no fury, so unite to accomplish wonders. But also like the first 300 movie, this film also uses the storytelling technique of the first film in which it told through the perspective of another person and as I notice whenever someone tells the story of anything (whether it is true or not) tends to exaggerate the details and make it come off as more melodramatic, thus I am able to swallow some of the more fantastical and over the top moments in the film. Also the fact that this film has a somewhat unqiue structure to other films I have seen, as it is not just a mere¬†sequel to the first film and more like a companion piece (it is a prequel and a sequel, while also taking place at the same time as the first film).

Also I liked that the Athenians have a different motivation and goal to that of the Spartas, which shows that the filmmakers at least tried when it comes to the characters. Also Eva Green was FANTASTIC in the role and was hands down the best thing about this film,

Overall, this is a film that I will defiantly buy on Blu Ray when it comes out.

Title: 300: Rise of an Empire - Official Trailer 1 [HD]
Comment:
Stop this crazy Hollywood led Iran phobia:

300- the cartoonish film retelling of the Spartans' defence of Thermopylae against a Persian horde - now has a sequel, 300: Rise of an Empire. How much of it plays fast and loose with the history, asks Paul Cartledge, professor of Greek culture at Cambridge University.

¬†¬†¬† 1. The first problem is the title. Which "Empire" is supposed to be on the rise here? The "Athenian Empire"? That didn't even begin to rise until at least two years after the events that the movie focuses on - the sea-battles of Artemisium and Salamis, both fought in 480 BC.
¬†¬†¬† 2. The movie gets under way with a wondrously unhistorical arrow. It is fired by Athenian hero Themistocles on the battlefield of Marathon near Athens in 490 BC, and it kills none other than Persian Great King Darius I, next to whom is standing son and successor Xerxes. Although Darius had launched the Persian expedition that came to grief at Marathon, he was not present there, nor was Xerxes.
¬†¬†¬† 3. From the Persians' Marathon defeat, which - historically - accounts for their revenge expedition under Xerxes, the scene shifts to the Persians' fleet a whole decade later. The fleet is under the command of a Greek woman - Queen Artemisia of Halicarnassus (modern Bodrum), played by Eva Green. Artemisia was real enough, we learn from Herodotus, her contemporary and historian of the Greco-Persian Wars. She was indeed a Greek queen, who did fight for the Persians at Salamis. But far from being admiral-in-chief of the Persian navy, she contributed a mere handful of warships out of the total of 600 or so.
¬†¬†¬† 4. The film-makers included one rather prolonged, explicit heterosexual sex scene. Utterly and completely fantastically it is between enemies Themistocles and Artemisia in the interim between the battles of Artemisium (presented as a Greek defeat - actually it was a draw) and Salamis. All in the name of diplomacy, naturally.
¬†¬†¬† 5. The crowning, climactic historical absurdity is the notion that in order for Themistocles and his Athenians to win at Salamis they needed the help of the massive Spartan navy which turns up just in the nick of time, commanded by another Greek queen, Gorgo (widow of Leonidas, the hero of 300), played by Lena Headey. Actually, Sparta contributed a mere 16 warships to the Greek fleet of some 400 ships at Salamis, and like Artemisia's they made absolutely no difference to the outcome, which was resoundingly and incontestably an Athenian victory.

Comment:
300 is just propaganda. The fact that there were also other Greeks there, including the Spartan slaves. And that the Spartans would have been unlikely to call someone else a boy-lover, because they had a long tradition of relationships between older and younger men. And the fact that the Spartan society was based on slave labour, which makes their speeches about freedom really absurd. Especially considering the fact that slavery was (mostly) illegal in Persia.
It's a fun movie, but like any movie, it has to simplify matters to fit them into two hours. There's an interesting essay on the historical truth of "300" by David Brin. Not perfect, but I guess it's a good starting point.

Comment:
From a viewpoint of someone with a history degree who has well studied the Greco-Persian wars:¬†
+ good scenery and ofc epic battle scenes¬†
+ amazing ship-battle scenes pretty close to reality with well designed trieres (greek ship)
+ good character build up on Artemisia (even if was completely made up)
- the ''superhuman'' Xerxes and his ''transformation''. I think they definetely overdid it on this one
- the death of Darius by Themistocles...the ancient equivalent of Hitler dying on the battle field after being shot by Roosevelt...
Overall, well worth its money-> 9/10 compared to the rest crappy modern action films

Comment:
Funny Historical Fact:

You see the Athenian protagonist? As you probably may know, he's Themistocles, the great General and Politician who was the main responsible for the outcome of those two simultaneous battles (Artemisium and Thermopyhlae) and others, since the time he engaged in a campaign of political investment in Naval Military, after learning about Persian strategies.

Did you knew that after all that, various Greek rulers and influent politicians (including Spartan) turned against him after some decisions he made that looked "too revolutionary"?

Themistocles went to live in exile in Argos, but his "old time friends" kept conspirating against him, accusing him of crimes that he never commited.

At last, it's said that the Great Hero "lost faith" in his homeland representatives (he actually fled from Greece in terror), and went to ASIA, where he served Artaxerxes I (King of PERSIA and son of XERXES I !!!) for the rest of his life. XP

see the truth behind real Greece that every one love and the reason people say west is Greece is because of a bad relation with Persia(Iran) today you know nothing about politics nor history, you are a pretender or a childish kid who excepts the lies, i mean come on don't you get it already!, they are trying to make people to think Persians are bad 10,375,370 this many people.Real Persians are indoEuropeans and religion is Zoroastrian one of the very first religions, not Muslim. Persians fought Arabs in around The Muslim conquest of Persia, also known as the Arab conquest of Iran led to the end of the Sasanian Empire in 651 and the eventual decline of the Zoroastrian religion in Iran. Arabs first attacked the Sassanid territory in 633, when general Khalid ibn Walid invaded Mesopotamia (what is now Iraq), which was the political and economic center of the Sassanid state.[3] Following the transfer of Khalid to the Roman front in the Levant, the Muslims eventually lost their holdings to Iranian counterattacks. The second invasion began in 636 under Saad ibn Abi Waqqas, when a key victory at the Battle of Qadisiyyah led to the permanent end of Sasanian control west of Iran. The Zagros mountains then became a natural barrier and border between the Rashidun Caliphate and the Sassanid Empire. Owing to continuous raids by Persians into the area, Caliph Umar ordered a full invasion of the Sasanian Iranian empire in 642, which was completed with the complete conquest of the Sasanians around 651. The quick conquest of Iran in a series of well coordinated multi-pronged attacks, directed by Caliph Umar from Medina several thousand miles from the battlefields in Iran, became his greatest triumph, contributing to his reputation as a great military and political strategist.
Iranian historians have sought to defend their forebears by using Arab sources to illustrate that "contrary to the claims of some historians, Iranians, in fact, fought long and hard against the invading Arabs." By 651, most of the urban centers in nces and Transoxiana, had come under the domination of the Arab armies. Many localities in Iran staged a defense against the invaders, but in the end none was able to repulse the invasion. Even after the Arabs had subdued the country, many cities rose in rebellion, killing the Arab governor or attacking their garrisons, but reinforcements from the caliphs succeeded in putting down all these rebellions and imposing the rule of Islam. The violent subjugation of Bukhara after many uprisings is a case in point. Conversion to Islam was, however, only gradual. In the process, many acts of violence took place, Zoroastrian scriptures were burnt and many mobads executed. Once conquered politically, the Persians began to reassert themselves by maintaining Persian language and culture. Regardless, Islam was adopted by many, for political, socio-cultural or spiritual reasons, or simply by persuasion, and became the dominant religion.¬†

The most important Greco-Persian battles¬†is here:

(547 BC) The collision between Greeks and Persians begun when Cyrus the Great conquered the Greek cities in Ionia region (Today's Turkey).

(499 ‚Äì 493 BC) The Greek cities ''Athens and Eretria'' supported the ''Ionian Revolt'' and the king of Persia, Mardonios, decided to destroy Athens and Eretria.

(492 BC) Persians conquered Thrace and the Greek Kingdom of Macedonia and many Greek islands.

(490 BC - Battle of Marathon):
(11.000) Greeks VS (20.000 - 100.000) Persians. (Greeks won)

(480 BC - Battle of Thermopylae):
(7.500 - 10.000 Greeks) VS (70.000 - 300.000 Persians). Persians won when ''Ephialtes'' betrayed the Greeks.

(480 BC - Naval Battle of Artemisium):
(270 Greek Ships) VS (800 Persian Ships). Persians won. Greeks retreated to Salamina.

(480 BC - Naval Battle of Salamis):
(378 Greek Ships) VS (800 - 1.000 Persian Ships). ¬†(Greeks won)

(479 BC - Battle of Plataea):
(40.000 Greeks) VS (70.000 - 120.000 Persians). ¬† ¬† (Greeks won)

(479 BC - Battle of Mycale):
(40.000 Greeks 250 Ships VS (60.000 Persians 300 Ships). (Greeks won)

(334 - 331 BC) Greeks with Alexander the Great attacked and completely destroyed the Persian Empire

(334 BC - Battle of the Granicus):
(47.000 Greeks) VS (25.000 Persians). (Greeks won)

(333 BC - Battle of Issus):
(40.000 Greeks) VS (50.000 - 100.000 Persians). (Greeks won)

(331 BC - Battle of Gaugamela):
(47.000 Greeks) VS (50.000 - 100.000 Persians). (Greeks won)

Title: 300: Rise of an Empire - Official Trailer 1 [HD]
Comment:
The Persian Empire( ¬†550‚Äì330 BC), or First Persian Empire,[11] was an empire in Western and Central Asia, founded in the 6th century BC by Cyrus the Great.[11] The dynasty draws its name from king Achaemenes, who ruled Persis between 705 BC and 675 BC. The empire expanded to eventually rule over significant portions of the ancient world, which at around 500 BC stretched from the Indus Valley in the east to Thrace and Macedon on the northeastern border of Greece. The Persian Empire would eventually control Egypt as well. It was ruled by a series of monarchs who unified its disparate tribes and nationalities by constructing a complex network of roads.
By the 600s BC, the Persians (Parsa)[12] had settled in the southwest Iranian plateau, bounded on the west by the Tigris River and on the south by the Persian Gulf; this region came to be their heartland.[13] It was from this region that Cyrus the Great would advance to defeat the Kingdom of Media, the Kingdom of Lydia, and the Babylonian Empire, to form the Persian Empire.
At the height of its power after the conquest of Egypt, the empire encompassed approximately 8 million square kilometers[14] spanning three continents: Asia, Africa and Europe. At its greatest extent, the empire included the modern territories of Iran, Iraq, Syria, Jordan, Israel, Palestine, Lebanon, all significant population centers of ancient Egypt as far west as Libya, Turkey, Thrace and Macedonia, much of the Black Sea coastal regions, Armenia, Georgia, Azerbaijan, much of Central Asia, Afghanistan, northern Saudi Arabia, Pakistan, and parts of Oman and the UAE.[6][7] It is noted in Western history as the antagonist foe of the Greek city states[13] during the Greco-Persian Wars, for emancipation of slaves including the Jewish people from their Babylonian captivity, and for instituting infrastructures such as a postal system, road systems, and the usage of an official language, Aramaic, throughout its territories. The empire had a centralised, bureaucratic administration under the King and a large professional army and civil services, inspiring similar developments in later empires.[15] The delegation of power to local governments eventually weakened the king's central authority, causing resources to be expended in attempts to subdue local rebellions.[13] This accounts for the dis-unification of the region by the time Alexander the Great invaded Persia in 334 BC.
This viewpoint however is challenged by some modern scholars who argue that the Persian Empire was not facing any such crisis around the time of Alexander, and that only internal succession struggles within the Persian family ever came close to weakening the empire.[13] Alexander, an avid admirer of Cyrus the Great,[16] would eventually cause the collapse of the empire and its disintegration around 330 BC into what later became the Ptolemaic Kingdom and Seleucid Empire, in addition to other minor territories which gained independence at that time. The Persian culture of the central plateau, however, continued to thrive and eventually reclaimed power by the 2nd century BC.[13]
The historical mark of the Persian Empire went far beyond its territorial and military influences and included cultural, social, technological and religious influences as well. Many Athenians adopted Persian customs in their daily lives in a reciprocal cultural exchange,[17] some being employed by, or allied to the Persian kings. The impact of Cyrus the Great's Edict of Restoration is mentioned in Judeo-Christian texts and the empire was instrumental in the spread of Zoroastrianism as far east as China. Even Alexander the Great, the man who would set out to conquer this vast empire, would respect its customs, by enforcing respect for the royal Persian kings including Cyrus the Great, and even by appearing in proskynesis, a Persian royal custom, despite stern Macedonian disapproval.[18][19] The Persian Empire would also set the tone for the politics, heritage and history of modern Persia (now called Iran).[20]
In 480 BC, it is estimated that 50 million[4] people lived in the Persian Empire.[21]

Comment:
Just want to give you guys the historical context for what this is based on:
AFTER Leiondas and his 300 Spartans and 500 Thebans fought at Thermopylae pass, the Persians routed the Greek army and moved on towards Athens. Themistocles (the new protagonist) was an Athenian General. He knew Athens could not be held, so he put the ENTIRE Athenian population on ships and sailed to another city. There the Athenian population could sees the flames of the Persians burning their city. Themistocles tricked the Persian fleet into thinking the Athenians would try to escape at night, tiring out the enemy all night. Then in the day his fleet attacked and destroyed the Persian navy. The battle of Salamis.

Title: 300: Rise of an Empire - Official Trailer 1 [HD]
Comment:
Ancient Greek historians and every available piece of Ancient evidence states otherwise. The Persians outlawed slavery. Sure it would have existed in some areas but for the most part it wasn't allowed. They did plenty of horrible shit and forced nations to fight for them, but the empire didn't support "slavery" as we would define it today. 

Look past your nationalistic facade for once.

Title: 300: Rise of an Empire - Official Trailer 1 [HD]
Comment: This is depending on how we define slavery. The nations Persia conquered were forced to contribute soldiers or give tribute. This is not slavery, it's effectively a kind of serfdom. Slavery is when people are treated as property and bought or sold, which was not the case in Ancient Persia. I understand completely how this could be seen as slavery to a Greek, who lived in independent city states, but the truth is that slavery as the Greek's would have understood it was outlawed in Persia.

The battle of Thermopylae happened in 300, but after that, i'm pretty sure everything else was fiction.
Also, this movie does have a stick of truth in it. It's based off of second persian invasion of greece (just like the first movie). Except this is after Thermopylae, Themistocles succeeded in luring the Persian navy into the Straits of Salamis, where the huge number of Persian ships became disorganised, and were beaten by the Allied fleet. This is likely what this movie is based on.

The battle of Salamis
480 BC
At the Persian council, Xerxes asked his generals, if they ought to fight. All of them responded positively, except Artemisia, the queen of Hallicarnassus in Karia. She told Xerxes, that if he did not attack, the Greeks would disperse.Attacking them was an unnecessary risk not only for the fleet, but for the land army as well. She proposed instead of a naval battle to lead the land army and take Peloponnesos.

Comment: Probably both. The Spartans and Athenians didn't particularly like each other, but they formed an alliance to fight off the Persians. The Spartans wanted to retreat to the Peloponessus and fight on land, but Themistocles realized they could lure the Persian fleet into the strait of Salamis and persuaded the Spartans to go along with his plan. They then trapped the Persian fleet in the strait of Salamis and annihilated them. Xerxes decided to leave part of his army and retreat back to Turkey.
